Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Study of Flammability, Mechanism and Heat/Mass Transfer Associated with Burning of Flame Retardant Polymer Nanocomposites

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336162/1336254
Mannan/Wang

Highly flammable polymers like poly (methyl methacrylate) used in homes for construction, in case of fire, cause an alarming number of deaths and property loss. The objective of this work is to facilitate the accomplishment of the ultimate goal of fire retardancy, extensive charring of the polymer matrix, which means that the polymer can be used at the service temperature, whereas in case of fire, it would rapidly char, limiting the production of combustible volatiles. This will be accomplished by forming new polymer nanocomposites which show synergistic effects of the two types of nanofillers: one forms a physical barrier and the other catalytically chars the polymer by changing its degradation pathway during burning. In view of the lack of qualitative and quantitative understanding of the fire retardant mechanism of each type of nanofiller, this research will focus on studying the kinetics and the mass and heat transfer processes involved in the burning of the polymer with and without the nanofillers, qualitatively using thermal analysis and quantitatively using cone-calorimeter experiments.

The new knowledge generated would be disseminated through publications, book sections, and fire safety courses at Texas A&M University and Oklahoma State University. The broad impact of this research is twofold, such that it would contribute to better understanding of the role of nanofillers in fire retardancy at the fundamental level and at the same time give a practical insight on the development of new and better fire retardant materials with the potential of replacing existing materials, providing enough time for timely evacuation and timely control of fires due to less heat release.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymers can be found in many homes in the United States, such as couches, bedding, baby products, and countless other household goods. One inherent disadvantage associated with those hydrocarbon-based materials is the potential fire hazards. One solution to this problem is to incorporate flame retardant additives into polymers. Many commercially available flame retardant additives such as tris (1,3-dichloro-2-propyl) phosphate (commonly known as TDCPP or chlorinated tris) have shown neurotoxicity in mammals. Some other traditional flame retardants have been restricted in their utility due to potential damage to the environment. The development of new, nontoxic, and environmentally friendly flame retardant materials is important to provide manufacturers with cheap alternatives but without a decrease in flame retardant performance. Flame retardant polymer nanocomposites have shown great promise due to their high effectiveness and potentially low toxicity. In this project, to develop a fundamental understanding of why polymer nanocomposite materials make such excellent fire-mitigation technologies, extensive studies have been conducted on kinetics and mass/heat transfers occurring during thermal pyrolysis of polymer nanocomposites using different thermal and morphological techniques, such as Cone Calorimeter, Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA), Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD). So far, this project has yielded 7 peer reviewed journal publications and 4 conference presentations, which contributes to generating and sharing new knowledge in the field of flame retardancy and combustion.

 

This project has motivated the development of procedures to produce nanocomposites using an in-situ based method. Different types of nanocomposite samples were successfully synthesized and tested by using different analytical tools, including cross-linked nanocomposites. Additionally, thermal behaviors and their temperature profiles of various polymers under pyrolysis conditions were studied by using software tool called COMSOL. Based on this study, a mathematical model which can predict the thermal behavior of polymers under pyrolysis has been developed and further validated, which will prove to be a breakthrough in the field as it will significantly reduce the time, infrastructure and efforts required in synthesizing and running hundreds of experiments for each new polymer composite to test their flame retardancy. Additionally, even at low concentration of nanoparticles, through the synergistic interaction of the formation of physical barriers and the formation of char in the condensed phase, the fire behavior performances of polymer nanocomposites have been improved, for example, burning intensity is reduced significantly. A deeper understanding of flame retardant mechanism of polymer nanocomposites has been gained from this project, which could give future researchers some insight into the design of new polymer nanocomposites used in other applications such as automobiles, aerospace coatings, adhesives, solar cells, packaging materials, sensors, membranes and other consumer goods.

 

Each graduate student who work or assist on this project, had the chance to be exposed to multidisciplinary knowledge from different fields of science and engineering such as material science, chemistry, combustion and safety. They received site specific training on calibration and operation with Cone Calorimeter at OSU Fire Protection & Safety Laboratory. The skills gained at this training aided the graduate students to perform future fire testing of the polymer nanocomposites. During the project, they also received training on collaborative work, data analysis and processing, scientific paper writing, and public presentation of results, which will prepare them for future career. This project directly expands the capabilities of OSU and TAMU while utilizing the already-existing investments of both universities.
